ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to identify and analyze different types of publics
I learned to think critically and differently about different groups of people and the social dynamics between different publics.
Studying the social theory behind communities of the world, combining academic performance theory with a variety of diverse, historic events and cultural moments.

I learned so much about collectivity, public performance, and how we define different groups. This was my first dive into performance theory and I loved every reading that we did -- so much food for thought that was exponentially increased by the participation of everyone in the class. I learned the most about how scholarship and knowledge can transcend traditionally "academic" boundaries, say a research paper format, and take a different medium or form that could be more conducive to the overall goal of the project.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Shilarna! Shilarna is the greatest instructor; she's so knowledgeable, kind, and accommodating. She always has our best interests at heart. and the readings she assigned were always engaging. Weaknesses: none

It was very interesting and I appreciated that you could get as much out of the course as you put in. It was easy to be part of discussions and stay engaged, but there was also grace if someone did not have the ability to complete all the assigned readings.

A strong performance theory course for the major. It was a little difficult to get under at first, but I walked away with a great learning experience and a new method of research! Fun topic to engage with.
I think making the research assignments visible before the week they are due would help students better plan their time.

Strengths were the people and the discussions! It felt as though everyone had something to say, based on personal experience and the readings. I reached conclusions I would have never reached because of interesting insights brought up by everyone, especially Professor Stokes! Everyone's final projects were also fascinating, and I really appreciated the research process. Weakness was that it got a bit unstructured towards the end of the class, but that was just because I was a bit further along in my research and the more free time was more helpful for other people.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! If you're interested in theatre and want to explore it in a more theoretical way, this is a really good class.
Yes! Especially for junior THST students looking to step up their research skills ahead of the senior thesis.

Yes! Studying publics is so cool and eye-opening. So much of the world opens up through this lens. Shilarna made sure to assign important texts from across various disciplines and genres. Shilarna is also just the best instructor and support system. Would def recommend to anyone!
Yes, absolutely. The students all brought different perspectives and it was incredibly interesting to hear them talk about their backgrounds and interests.
Yes! Great performance theory credit for the TDPS major.

YES! Everyone, no matter your major, should take this class. I learned so much about how scholarship can be best articulated, how publics and narratives are constructed, and why defining an audience is so important. We discussed incredibly fun things (Beyonce vs Donald Trump, pageants, protests, music festivals, etc), but everything related to a larger commentary on society, scholarship, how we present information, and how we view ourselves that will be helpful to everyone. It's a low stress course that develops research skills, provides awesome perspectives, and felt like a breath of life to my semester.
